appropriations: The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) requests $175,000 (HB431_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-24-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position needed to help administer the supportive housing special fund. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: Regarding H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, it is difficult to determine whether the proposed SHSF would be self-sustaining. [8]
agency_impact: The Department of Human Services (DHS) respectfully requests that the provision regarding at least two bidders for a Kauhale project estimated cost of over $1 million be deleted. [8] DHS is also concerned that the two-bid minimum may delay project development in certain communities if only one bid is received. [8] The State Procurement Office (SPO) recommends that the procurement exemption language exempting the corporation from complying with chapter 103D be removed. [8]
economic_impact: Testimony indicates that people offered supportive housing spent 23 % fewer days in hospitals, had 33 % fewer emergency room visits, and spent 42 % fewer days in nursing homes over a year. [8] Furthermore, supportive housing reduces recidivism. [8] A study by Hawaii based organization Partners in Care revealed that the recidivism rate for individuals who received housing support was 12.8% versus 50% without housing support. [8]
policy_impact: As a matter of general policy, the Department of Budget and Finance (B&F) does not support the creation of any special fund, which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS. [8] The State Procurement Office (SPO) states that exemptions to the Hawaii Procurement Code have always been a concern. [8] Exemptions to the Code mean that all procurements made with taxpayer monies will not have the same oversight, accountability and transparency requirements mandated by those procurements processes provided in the code. [8]

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: New testimony includes a request from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) for $175,000 (HB431_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-24-25_.PDF.txt) for one full-time equivalent position. [8] The Department of Human Services (DHS) now requests the deletion of the provision requiring at least two bidders for Kauhale projects estimated to cost over $1 million. [8] The State Procurement Office submitted new testimony recommending the removal of the procurement exemption for the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [8] The Department of Budget and Finance raised new concerns that the special fund may not meet statutory requirements and that it is difficult to determine if it would be self-sustaining. [8] [8] New testimony also provides specific data points on potential economic impacts, such as reduced healthcare utilization and lower recidivism rates for individuals in supportive housing.
